narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of Jewish history and Muslim history. Ability to analyze primary sources
Development and varying relationships of Jewish communities living under Muslim rule.
I learned a lot about Jewish and Muslim histories during the 7th and 16th centuries.
Learned how to extract important information from readings and lecture notes for exams. Learned how to review primary soruces.
I learned about the life of Jews in the Muslim lands. This course was a great overview that doesnt require any prior knowledge in Jewish history.

I learned a great deal about the history of Judaism as well as its relationship to Islam and Christianity. I think we learned some key aspects into the difference between identifiers for individuals and groups of Muslim/ Jewish individuals. I also learned how to close read primary sources as well as analyze them as if I had no prior knowledge of the sources.
I really appreciated the fact that we analyzed both a huge time period while focusing on individual people
Stuff on the history of Jews in Muslim lands and evaluating and writing on sources.

I learned a lot about how Jewish history intersected with the histories of Muslim and Christian empires. This course equipped me with primary sources and terminology specific to these intersections and interactions between different religious communities.
n/a
Loved learning about Jews in Muslim Lands, especially since Im part Sephardic Jewish

I learned a lot about an area of history that I didn't know much about before. The course goes through Jewish history in several different Muslim and Muslim-adjacent societies and explains the social and political structures that impacted Jewish life.
I learned a lot about Jewish and Muslim history.

This class provided me with the opportunity to delve more deeply into primary sources and the personal narratives of Jews, Muslims, and Christians throughout the Mediterranean. I hadn't previously encountered many of these perspectives, so this class was super cool!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More visual aids and materials posted on Canvas. Theres no way to review, and if you miss something in class its pretty much over since theres no slides o just really barebones outlines with maybe 30-40 words. Also its hard to follow in class given the lack of slides

Strengths: good lecturer 

Weakness: content was boring sometimes
Strength: lots of good information given, interesting material
This course is very comprehensive in its subject matter so I imagine it is a good starting point for history majors (which I am not).

I think the main weaknesses are a lack of organization in the course and a lack of clarity around instructions for the final paper. I think including a slide show presentation to cover the notes would go a long way for the organization.
Strengths: very intriguing

Professor Marcuss lecture is gem and I enjoyed every class. Maybe one thing of improvement can be done with class reading materials. I thought the packet was quite expensive, an free online version of it wouldve been really helpful.

I think that Professor Marcus is extremely knowledgeable and always has content to discuss during class. He is relatively organized, sticking to an outline that is very helpful for exams but it would be useful if lecture notes or slides or definitions were posted along with the outline as when we would ask clarifying questions he often said the answers were in the texts if we read them. I think that this course was great in terms of learning new things each week and providing a new perspective on various faiths. One weakness was that the second midterm was during reading week which was more stressful than if it were the week or two weeks before.

Strengths Prof Marcus provides the materials to do well in this class and lectures well
Weakness: it is only a lecture and doesn't cover all the stuff on the outline he provides
It is pretty good, I do not know what would be improved on

The course is focused on primary sources, which is one of its great strengths. Prof. Marcus encourages students to derive history from the primary sources, which is later supplemented by broader overviews which he offers during lectures. I do not think the course has any weaknesses.
n/a
The course is a very comprehensive treatment of Jewish history in the Muslim world. An online version of the course text would be helpful.
Nothing - loved the course

The course covers super interesting material and the readings are carefully chosen to cover many different aspects of Jewish life in Muslim lands. Professor Marcus brings up a variety of topics in his lectures but they can at times be difficult to follow. I think the course could be improved by having two 50-min lectures and a discussion section with a TF to be able to go through the sheer volume of material discussed in the class. I also wished that the final essay could have involved research instead of just comparing primary sources  the opportunity to research into this part of history might have been interesting.
Strengths: Professor Marcus, the course structure (two exams and a painless paper).

Unless you have a good understanding of Jewish history already, this class will be an uphill battle. Coming from a Jewish parochial school background, I came in with a decent grasp of the background information and was able to help out classmates who weren't familiar with this material.
I wish there were visuals, like a powerpoint. Nice use of primary sources.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, decent choice for a pre-industrial or geographical distributional requirement. Expect an old-school lecture style, fascinating content, minimal flexibility, and a very manageable workload.
Yes it was relatively easy and very informative on these histories and issues.
Yes, if you're interested in Muslims and Jewish philosophy and history it's very specific
Yes, info is very interesting and professor is very willing to help and facilitate more knowledge.
I would recommend this course to another student, but only if they have a prior knowledge of Jewish and Muslim history before enrolling.
Yes, great professor. Very interesting.

Yes, definitely. This class covers a very niche topic but successfully relates to the modern world, especially its current political conflicts. It is quite interesting to learn major historical events such as the Crusades and the rise of Christianity from a perspective different from how we usually learn. I definitely recommend this to any major, especially to those who are looking for a fourth or a fifth class since this class doesnt have a high workload.

I would, but only if the student is willing to force themselves to remain engaged during all the lectures. I found towards the end of the year that it could be a bit difficult to remain focused but overall, the content was interesting. It's a great course to take to broaden one's knowledge/ cultural knowledge.
Yes! I thought I learned a lot and Prof Marcus was very helpful and seemed to care about all his students
Yea it is decent.

Absolutely. I would recommend this course to any student who has a genuine interest in Jewish history. Lectures can be tiresome at times, so it is important to come into this class eager to learn and ready to take proper notes.
n/a
Yes this course was very interesting and the professor is a great lecturer.
Depends on if theyre interested in Jewish history or not
Yes, I did not expect to like this course as much as I did. The paper was fun to write, and the exams were fair. Professor Marcus's lectures are funny and informative.
If you want to get the most out of this class, do the readings! Otherwise, this class is very laid back and interesting. Do be aware that this class functions more so as a lecture than a seminar.
